SessionStateSection Class

Definition

Configures the session state for a Web application.

In this Article

public sealed class SessionStateSection : System.Configuration.ConfigurationSection
Inheritance
Object
ConfigurationElement
System.Configuration.ConfigurationSection
SessionStateSection

Remarks

The SessionStateSection class refers to the element in the Machine.config or Web.config configuration file identified by the sessionState tag.

When a new client begins interacting with a Web application, a session ID is issued and associated with all the subsequent requests from the same client during the time that the session is valid. This ID is used to maintain server-side state associated with the client session across requests. The SessionStateSection controls how the ASP.NET application establishes and maintains this association on behalf of each client.

This mechanism is very flexible and gives you the ability to host session-state information out of process and to track state without using cookies, among other things.

Constructors

SessionStateSection()

Initializes a new instance of the SessionStateSection class.

public SessionStateSection ();

Remarks

The SessionStateSection constructor is not intended to be used directly from your code. It is called by the ASP.NET configuration system. You obtain an instance of the SessionStateSection class by using the GetSection method.

Properties

AllowCustomSqlDatabase

Gets or sets a value indicating whether the user can specify the initial catalog value in the stem.Web.Configuration.SessionStateSection.SqlConnectionString* property.

public bool AllowCustomSqlDatabase { get; set; }
Value
Boolean

true if the user is allowed to specify the catalog; otherwise, false. The default value is false.

CompressionEnabled

Gets or sets a value that indicates whether compression is enabled for session-state data.

public bool CompressionEnabled { get; set; }
Value
Boolean

true if compression is enabled; otherwise false. The default is false.

Remarks

When the CompressionEnabled value is set to true, ASP.NET uses the GZipStream class to compress and expand session-state data.

Cookieless

Gets or sets a value indicating whether cookies are used to identify client sessions.

public System.Web.HttpCookieMode Cookieless { get; set; }
Value
HttpCookieMode

true if all requests are treated as cookieless, or false if no requests are treated as cookieless, or one of the HttpCookieMode values. The default value in ASP.NET version 2.0 is HttpCookieMode. In earlier versions, the default value was false.

Remarks

There are two ways that session state can store the unique ID that associates the client with a server session: by storing an HTTP cookie on the client or by encoding the session ID in the URL. Storing the session ID in the cookie is more secure but requires the client browser to support cookies.

For applications that allow clients that do not support cookies, such as a variety of mobile devices, the session ID may be stored in the URL. The URL option has several drawbacks. It requires that the links on the site be relative and that the page be redirected at the beginning of the session with new query-string values, and it exposes the session ID right in the query string, where it can be picked up for use in a security attack.

You are encouraged to use the cookieless mode only if you need to support clients that lack cookie support.

Session state also supports two additional options: HttpCookieMode and HttpCookieMode. The former enables the session-state module to determine what mode (cookie or cookieless) is used on a per-client basis based on the browser capabilities. The HttpCookieMode option performs a handshake with the browser to verify whether a cookie may be stored, and therefore requires an additional request to make the determination. If you need to support cookieless clients, strongly consider using HttpCookieMode to generate cookieless URLs only for clients that require them.

Note

With UP.Browser 4.1 or UP.Browser 3.2, Redirect always behaves as if the value of the SupportsRedirectWithCookie property of the HttpBrowserCapabilities object is false, unless the Cookieless property in the SessionState section of Web.config has been explicitly set to true.

In ASP.NET version 1.1, the options for this setting were true or false, but with ASP.NET 2.0, the choices are expanded, and HttpCookieMode is now the default setting. If your Web application has the Cookieless property set to a Boolean value, then Redirect should work as expected for these browsers.

CookieName

Gets or sets the cookie name.

public string CookieName { get; set; }
Value
String

The name of the HTTP cookie to use for session identification.

Remarks

The default value is "ASP.NET_SessionId".

CustomProvider

Gets or sets the name of the custom provider from the stem.Web.Configuration.SessionStateSection.Providers* collection.

public string CustomProvider { get; set; }
Value
String

The custom provider name.

Remarks

The provider is only used when the session-state mode is set to SessionStateMode.

ElementProperty 

protected override System.Configuration.ConfigurationElementProperty ElementProperty { get; }
Value
ConfigurationElementProperty

To be added.

Mode

Gets or sets a value specifying where to store the session state.

public System.Web.SessionState.SessionStateMode Mode { get; set; }
Value
SessionStateMode

One of the SessionStateMode values. The default value is SessionStateMode.

Remarks

The SessionStateMode is not a required attribute and can be inherited from a higher level in the configuration hierarchy or from the default value. However, the configuration handler for this section will always write out the mode based on the current inherited value when writing this section.

PartitionResolverType

Gets or sets a value specifying where to store the session state.

public string PartitionResolverType { get; set; }
Value
String

A value specifying where to store the session state, or an empty string ("").

Remarks

If the PartitionResolverType property is specified, the SqlConnectionString property and StateConnectionString property are ignored. The PartitionResolverType can be locked via the LockAttributes property like other properties within the sessionState Element (ASP.NET Settings Schema) element. The connection string returned by the PartitionResolverType will be used on every request to connect to the appropriate server location for the remainder of the request. If the connection string is invalid, ASP.NET will throw the same exception that is thrown when the configured connection string to the server is invalid.

This property is used to partition session-state data across multiple backend nodes when in SQL or state-server mode.

Properties 

protected override System.Configuration.ConfigurationPropertyCollection Properties { get; }
Value
ConfigurationPropertyCollection

To be added.

Providers

Gets the current ProviderSettingsCollection providers.

public System.Configuration.ProviderSettingsCollection Providers { get; }
Value
ProviderSettingsCollection

The collection containing the SessionStateSection providers.

Remarks

This property refers to the information contained by the configuration tag identified by the providers element.

RegenerateExpiredSessionId

Gets or sets a value indicating whether the session Id will be re-issued when an expired session ID is specified by the client.

public bool RegenerateExpiredSessionId { get; set; }
Value
Boolean

true if the session ID must be regenerated; otherwise, false. The default value is true.

Remarks

By default, only cookieless URLs are reissued when RegenerateExpiredSessionId is enabled.

SessionIDManagerType

Gets or sets a value specifying the fully qualified type of session ID Manager.

public string SessionIDManagerType { get; set; }
Value
String

A fully qualified type of session ID Manager.

Remarks

The SessionIDManagerType overrides session ID generation and management for custom session ID management schemes. The default value is an empty string ("").

SqlCommandTimeout

Gets or sets the duration time-out for the SQL commands using the SQL Server session state mode.

public TimeSpan SqlCommandTimeout { get; set; }
Value
TimeSpan

The amount of time, in seconds, after which a SQL command will time out. The default is 30 seconds.

SqlConnectionRetryInterval

Gets or sets the time interval that should elapse before ASP.NET reconnects to the database.

public TimeSpan SqlConnectionRetryInterval { get; set; }
Value
TimeSpan

The time interval that should elapse before ASP.NET reconnects to the database.

Remarks

The SqlConnectionRetryInterval specifies the time interval in seconds before reconnecting to the database when a connection error has occurred.

SqlConnectionString

Gets or sets the SQL connection string.

public string SqlConnectionString { get; set; }
Value
String

The SQL connection string. Its default value is the generic string: "data source=127.0.0.1;Integrated Security=SSPI"

Remarks

This sqlConnectionString attribute is required when Mode is set to SessionStateMode.

Note

To use the SessionStateMode session state mode, you must run the InstallSqlState.sql SQL script (which is installed in [drive:]\WINDOWS\Microsoft.NET\Framework\VersionNumber as part of the default .NET Framework installation) on the computer running SQL Server that will store the session state. This creates a database called ASPState with new stored procedures and creates new ASPStateTempApplications and ASPStateTempSessions tables in the TempDB database.

StateConnectionString

Gets or sets the state server connection string.

public string StateConnectionString { get; set; }
Value
String

The state server connection string.

Remarks

This property specifies the server name and the port when the session state is stored remotely. The stateConnectionString attribute is required when the Mode is set to SessionStateMode.

Note

Make sure the ASP.NET state service is running on the remote server that stores the session-state information. This service is installed with ASP.NET and is located by default at [drive:]\WINDOWS\Microsoft.NET\Framework\VersionNumber\aspnet_state.exe.

StateNetworkTimeout

Gets or sets the amount of time the network connection between the Web server and the state server can remain idle.

public TimeSpan StateNetworkTimeout { get; set; }
Value
TimeSpan

The time, in seconds, that the network connection between the Web server and the state server can remain idle before the session is abandoned. The default value is 10 seconds.

Remarks

This sessionStateSection attribute is required when the Mode property is set to SessionStateMode.

Timeout

Gets or sets the session time-out

public TimeSpan Timeout { get; set; }
Value
TimeSpan

The session time-out, in minutes. The default value is 20 minutes.

Remarks

The Timeout property cannot be set to a value greater than 525,601 minutes (1 year).

UseHostingIdentity

Gets or sets a value specifying the whether the session state will use client impersonation when available, or will always revert to the hosting identity.

public bool UseHostingIdentity { get; set; }
Value
Boolean

true if Web application should revert to hosting identity; otherwise, false. The default value is true.

Methods

PostDeserialize() 

protected override void PostDeserialize ();
